message.content:
To calculate how many notes can fit into one notepad, we need to know the size of each sheet after folding. Each piece of paper is folded three times, so it's divided into eight equal parts. When you cut along the lines, each letter-size piece will now be 8 smaller sheets.

A standard letter size paper is 8.5 x 11 inches. After folding and cutting, each sheet will measure approximately 5/8 x 3 7/8 inches (it's not exact due to the angles of folds).

Now we can calculate how many notes will fit on one side of the paper: 
Length = 5/8 * 11 = 6.875 inches
Width = 3 7/8 * 8.5 = 24.6875 inches
Area per side = 6.875 x 24.6875 = 170.19 sq inches
Since there are eight notes on one sheet, the total area of notes in a single sheet is:
Total area for one sheet = 170.19 * 8 = 1361.52 sq inches

Now let's calculate how many sheets can fit into a notepad. Let's assume that the height of the notepad is around half an inch (which would make it comfortable to hold) and each sheet occupies about 0.8 inch in height. So, we have:
Height of one sheet = 0.8 inches
Number of sheets per notepad = Height of the notepad / Height of a single sheet = 0.5 inches / 0.8 inches ≈ 0.625 sheets (approximately)

Now we can find out how many notes would be in a single notepad:
Number of notes per side = 170.19 sq inches / 1361.52 sq inches = 0.1267448
Since there are two sides to the sheet, the total number of notes per notepad is 0.1267448 * 2 = 0.2534896

Now we can calculate how long the notepad would last if someone wrote ten notes per day:
Number of days for one notepad to last = Number of notes in a single notepad / Notes written per day = 0.2534896 / 10 = 0.02534896 days

To convert this into years, months, weeks, and days:
Years = 0.02534896 * (365/365) ≈ 0.0009 days ≈ 0 seconds
Months = 0.02534896 * (12/365) ≈ 0.0027 months ≈ 0 weeks
Weeks = 0.02534896 * (52/365) ≈ 0.0053 weeks ≈ 0 days
Days = 0.02534896 days ≈ 0 seconds

So, the notepad would last for about 0 seconds or 0 years, months, and weeks, which means it would never run out if someone wrote ten notes per day on it!
